answers.answer: How long have you been on your current dosages of levo and T3 med?Many of your symptoms are indicative of hypothyroidism and your low levels of thyroid hormones bear that out, however, some of your symptoms indicate that you may have other issues going on at the same time...Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is separate from hypothyroidism and is treated differently.  It's related to insulin resistance and is, often, treated with meformin and more specifically, a diabetic type diet, consisting of foods that are low glycemic - meaning they won't spike your blood sugar levels. Have you been tested for type II diabetes?Weight gain can be associated with, hypo, PCOS or insulin resistance.  Pins and needles can be associated with vitamin B-12 deficiency.Stinging, foamy urine doesn't, typically, go with any of the above and should be checked out by a urologist or uro/gyn in case you have an infection

What is your A1c level?  Even in the normal range, you could have pre-diabetes/insulin resistance.Your folate level is too low; are you supplementing that?  You need to get a body ready type of folate, not the typical folic acid.Your B-12 is also too low in the range.  I find that I have to keep my B-12 at the very top of its range in order to keep symptoms at bay.  My lab uses a range of 200-1100 and they actually put a note on the lab report that anything less than 500 can cause symptoms of deficiency.  Some countries, such as Japan consider anything less than 500 deficient.  You should be supplementing B-12, as well.  Methylcobalamin is body ready and works better for most of us than cyanocobalamin, which has to be converted to methylcobalamin.Are you supplementing vitamin D to bring your level up?Many doctors don't connect vitamin deficiencies (or low levels), with symptoms... talk to your doctor and try to correct all of these and also the thyroid levels.

question: Could someone please interpret my results and symptoms. I take 150mcg levo and 10mcg t3, should endo be raising t3 in line with levo?SymptomsStinging and foamy urineConstipationMuscle aches and painsEczemaPolycystic ovariesHair lossEyebrow lossCold handsCold feetPins and needlesFeeling coldBags under eyesBloodshot eyesLoss of appetiteEasy weight gainThank youTSH: 4.10 (0.2 - 4.2)Free T4: 14.3 (12 - 22)Free T3: 3.5 (3.1 - 6.8)Thyroid peroxidase abs: 285 (<34)Thyroglobulin abs: 362 (<115)
title: Results advice required please
